newsitem.title: POLAND: ROW ERUPTS IN POLAND OVER DENIED CHURCH FUNERAL.
newsitem.headline: ROW ERUPTS IN POLAND OVER DENIED CHURCH FUNERAL.

text.p: Many Polish priests tried to explain to their congregations on Sunday why a prominent pro-abortion gynaecologist had been denied a Catholic burial last week in the central city of Lodz.
"People, come to your senses," exhorted the homilist at St Andrew's Church near Reuters Warsaw bureau. "Even Catholics have become muddled by all the media publicity."

"Professor (Waclaw) Dec was a declared non-believer who never darkened a church doorway, and he publicly advocated the killing of unborn infants. Allowing a Catholic funeral would have meant sowing demoralisation."

According to Catholic Canon Law, a funeral mass may be denied to heretics, apostates, schismatics, those who order cremation as a sign of religious defiance and others who have not not retracted public violations of Church teachings.
With the exception of a statement in defence of the denial by Episcopate spokesman Bishop Tadeusz Pieronek, the media have largely publicised views critical of the move.
"I am a practising Catholic but from today on I won't throw a penny into the collection basket," an irate woman told the daily Super Express in front of the locked church.
"Ten years ago the professor saved my life and thanks to him I now have a seven-year-old son," another woman said.
"To my mind he was a better Christian than the bishop," a middle-aged man told public television.
He was one of some 1,000 people who had come to pay their respects after seeing Dec's obituarary in the press.
The requiem mass was denied on orders from the Archbishop of Lodz, Wladyslaw Ziolek.
Dec, who had headed the local Institute of Gynaecology and Obstetrics, had been a champion of abortion rights and several years ago had been voted Lodz's "Man of the Year".
At the last moment, Dec's family arranged for a graveside service conducted by a military chaplain not under the archbishop's jurisdiction.
